title: Trent Alexander-Arnold
text:
Trent John Alexander-Arnold (born 7 October 1998) is an English professional <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who plays as a <a href="right-back">right-back</a> for club <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> and the <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England national team</a>. Known for his range of passing and providing assists, he is regarded as one of the best right-backs in world football.
Alexander-Arnold joined Liverpool's academy in 2004 and captained the club across its youth levels. He made his senior debut in 2016, at age 18, and played in back-to-back <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> finals in <a href="2018%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20Final">2018</a> and <a href="2019%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20Final">2019</a>, winning the latter and being named in the Champions League Squad of the Season. These appearances made Alexander-Arnold the youngest player to start in consecutive finals in the competition. In the same year, he won the <a href="2019%20UEFA%20Super%20Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a> and the <a href="2019%20FIFA%20Club%20World%20Cup">FIFA Club World Cup</a>. In domestic football, he won the 2019–20 <a href="PFA%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">PFA Young Player of the Year</a> and the inaugural <a href="Premier%20League%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Season">Premier League Young Player of the Season</a> awards, has twice been named in the <a href="PFA%20Team%20of%20the%20Year">PFA Team of the Year</a>, and helped end Liverpool's <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Liverpool%20F.C.%20season">30-year league title drought</a> by winning the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Premier%20League">2019–20 Premier League</a>.
Alexander-Arnold has also represented England at various youth levels and made his senior debut in 2018. He has since featured at the <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>, where he became only the fourth teenager to start a match for England in the tournament, and in the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20UEFA%20Nations%20League">2018–19 UEFA Nations League</a>, where his nation finished in third place in the inaugural edition of the competition.
Early life, education and early career.
Trent John Alexander-Arnold was born on 7 October 1998 in <a href="West%20Derby">West Derby</a>, Liverpool. He attended St Matthew's Catholic Primary School, before later enrolling at <a href="St%20Mary%27s%20College%2C%20Crosby">St Mary's</a>, in <a href="Crosby%2C%20Merseyside">Crosby</a>. When he was six years old, local football club <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> hosted a half-term camp to which a number of pupils from his school were invited, and his was one of the names drawn from a hat to attend. There, he was spotted by academy coach Ian Barrigan who subsequently approached his parents to offer him the chance to join the club's academy. He began training two-to-three times a week, and in a variety of different positions, before later going on to captain the club at U16 and U18 level under coach <a href="Pepijn%20Lijnders">Pepijn Lijnders</a>. In the intervening period, at the age of 14, he left St. Mary's to enroll at <a href="Rainhill%20High%20School">Rainhill High School</a>, an educational institution which shares an affiliation with the football club.
Club career.
Early professional career.
During his time in Liverpool's academy Alexander-Arnold converted from a <a href="Midfielder%23Wide%20midfielder">outside midfielder</a> to a right-back. It was the position that offered him the clearest path to the first team and he excelled in his new role, being singled out by former Liverpool captain <a href="Steven%20Gerrard">Steven Gerrard</a>, who tipped him to have a bright future at the club in his autobiography. As a result of his rapid progression, and in the buildup to the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Liverpool%20F.C.%20season">2015–16 season</a>, Alexander-Arnold was selected in the first team squad by <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> <a href="Brendan%20Rodgers">Brendan Rodgers</a> for the team's final pre-season <a href="Friendly%20%28association%20football%29">friendly</a> against <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a> where he marked his unofficial debut for the club in a 2–1 win.
Liverpool.
2016–17 season: Development and breakthrough.
Having previously taken part in Liverpool's pre-season tour of the United States, Alexander-Arnold made his professional debut on 25 October 2016, starting in a 2–1 victory over <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a> in the fourth round of the <a href="EFL%20Cup">EFL Cup</a>. He was <a href="Penalty%20card%23Yellow%20card">booked</a> in the first half for a foul on <a href="Ben%20Davies%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201993%29">Ben Davies</a>, which he later revealed could have ended in him being sent off, before being <a href="Substitute%20%28association%20football%29">substituted</a> for first-choice right-back <a href="Nathaniel%20Clyne">Nathaniel Clyne</a> in the 68th minute. Despite the indiscretion, his performance earned a spot in the EFL Cup Team of the Round alongside teammate <a href="Daniel%20Sturridge">Daniel Sturridge</a>.
Alexander-Arnold's breakthrough into the first team was rewarded with a new long-term contract in November and he started in Liverpool's next EFL Cup match later that month against <a href="Leeds%20United%20F.C.">Leeds United</a>. He was named <a href="Man%20of%20the%20Match">Man of the Match</a> for his performance after registering his first <a href="Assist%20%28football%29">assist</a> for the club by setting up <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a> <a href="Divock%20Origi">Divock Origi</a> for the opening goal of a 2–0 win for Liverpool. He then made his Premier League debut on 14 December, coming on as a late substitute in a 3–0 win over <a href="Middlesbrough%20F.C.">Middlesbrough</a>, and made his first league start in a 1–1 draw with <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> on 15 January 2017. In May, having made 12 appearances across all competitions, he was named Liverpool's Young Player of the Season and was also nominated for the <a href="Professional%20Development%20League">Premier League 2</a> Player of the Season award.
2017–18 season: First Champions League Final.
In the buildup to the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Liverpool%20F.C.%20season">2017–18 season</a>, regular right-back Clyne suffered a serious back injury which afforded Alexander-Arnold the opportunity to rotate with <a href="Joe%20Gomez%20%28footballer%29">Joe Gomez</a> during the early stages of the campaign. On 15 August 2017, he scored his first goal for the club when he struck home from a <a href="Direct%20free%20kick">free kick</a> in a 2–1 first leg <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> play-off round win over <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> team <a href="TSG%201899%20Hoffenheim">Hoffenheim</a>. In doing so, he became the third youngest player to score on his European debut for Liverpool, after <a href="Michael%20Owen">Michael Owen</a> and <a href="David%20Fairclough">David Fairclough</a>. During the group stages of the competition, Alexander-Arnold scored again in a 7–0 <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> win over <a href="NK%20Maribor">Maribor</a> on 17 October, a result which was the joint-largest ever away win in the competition, and largest away win by an English club. He then scored his first Premier League goal for Liverpool on <a href="Boxing%20Day">Boxing Day</a>, netting in a 5–0 win over <a href="Swansea%20City%20F.C.">Swansea City</a> at <a href="Anfield">Anfield</a>.
In March the following year, Alexander-Arnold endured his most difficult spell with the club to date, after struggling against <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a> winger <a href="Wilfried%20Zaha">Wilfried Zaha</a> and Manchester United's <a href="Marcus%20Rashford">Marcus Rashford</a> in successive weeks. Nonetheless, he retained his position in Liverpool's starting line-up to become the youngest English player to start in a Champions League quarter-final match and performed strongly in a 3–0 win over English rivals <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a> in April. His performance saw him named Man of the Match and earned him praise from the media for his ability to nullify City winger <a href="Leroy%20San%C3%A9">Leroy Sané</a>. He impressed again in the reverse fixture as Liverpool eliminated City 5–1 on <a href="Two-legged%20tie">aggregate</a> to advance to the semi-finals of the competition for the first time in 10 years. On 10 May, his domestic and European form was rewarded when he won the Liverpool Young Player of the Season award for the second season running. Later that month, he became the youngest Liverpool player to start in a <a href="2018%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20Final">Champions League final</a> when he was named in the starting line-up against two-time reigning champions, <a href="Real%20Madrid%20CF">Real Madrid</a>. Tasked with marking <a href="Cristiano%20Ronaldo">Cristiano Ronaldo</a>, he performed admirably though Liverpool ultimately succumbed to a 3–1 defeat. Following the conclusion of the season, in which he scored three goals in 33 appearances across all competitions, he was nominated for the <a href="Golden%20Boy%20%28award%29">Golden Boy</a> award where he was later voted runner-up to <a href="AFC%20Ajax">Ajax</a> defender, <a href="Matthijs%20de%20Ligt">Matthijs de Ligt</a>.
2018–19 season: Regular starter and Champions League title.
During the early stages of the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Premier%20League">following season</a>, he made his 50th appearance for Liverpool when he started in a 2–1 victory over Tottenham; the same opposition against whom he had made his debut almost two years prior. In October, he was one of 10 players nominated for the inaugural <a href="Kopa%20Trophy">Kopa Trophy</a>, an award presented by "<a href="France%20Football">France Football</a>" to the best young player under the age of 21, and ultimately ended sixth in the voting polls, having received votes from Owen, <a href="Denis%20Law">Denis Law</a> and <a href="Pavel%20Nedv%C4%9Bd">Pavel Nedvěd</a>. He continued to enhance his burgeoning reputation in the months thereafter and was consistently listed in reports by the <a href="International%20Centre%20for%20Sports%20Studies">CIES</a> as the world's most valuable full-back from a transfer value perspective. Alexander-Arnold elevated his game further following the turn of the year and, on 27 February 2019, became the youngest player, aged 20 years and 143 days, to record three assists in a single Premier League match when he set up <a href="Sadio%20Man%C3%A9">Sadio Mané</a> twice and <a href="Virgil%20van%20Dijk">Virgil van Dijk</a> once in a 5–0 win over <a href="Watford%20F.C.">Watford</a>. Less than two months later, he became the fifth-youngest player to reach 50 Premier League appearances for the club, behind Owen, <a href="Raheem%20Sterling">Raheem Sterling</a>, <a href="Robbie%20Fowler">Robbie Fowler</a> and Gerrard, when he started in a 3–1 win over <a href="Southampton%20F.C.">Southampton</a>. His domestic form was rewarded later in April when he was nominated for the <a href="PFA%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">PFA Young Player of the Year</a> award, although the award was won by Manchester City's Sterling, and he was later named in the <a href="PFA%20Team%20of%20the%20Year">PFA Team of the Year</a> alongside Liverpool teammates van Dijk, Mané and <a href="Andrew%20Robertson">Andrew Robertson</a>.
His creative prowess came to the fore once again in May when, during a 3–2 win over <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a>, Alexander-Arnold equalled the Premier League record for the most assists by a defender in a season, with his two assists in the match raising his tally to 11. It also saw him and Robertson, who had 11 assists of his own, become the first set of defenders from the same team to record double figures for assists in the same season. Three days later, with Liverpool trailing <a href="FC%20Barcelona">Barcelona</a> 3–0 on aggregate after a first-leg defeat, he recorded two more assists, including an "instinctive corner" for Origi's winning goal, to help the club to a 4–3 aggregate victory and progress to a second consecutive Champions League final. On the final day of the domestic season, Alexander-Arnold assisted Mané in a 2–0 win over <a href="Wolverhampton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wolverhampton Wanderers</a> to break the Premier League record for the most assists by a defender in a domestic campaign, with 12, surpassing previous holders <a href="Andy%20Hinchcliffe">Andy Hinchcliffe</a>, <a href="Leighton%20Baines">Leighton Baines</a> and Robertson. He then started in the <a href="2019%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20Final">Champions League Final</a>, a 2–0 win over Tottenham, and became the youngest player to start in two successive finals in the competition, breaking the record set by <a href="A.C.%20Milan">A.C. Milan</a>'s <a href="Christian%20Panucci">Christian Panucci</a> in 1995. He was later named in the competition's Team of the Season and nominated for the <a href="UEFA%20Club%20Football%20Awards%23Best%20Defender">Defender of the Season</a> award.
2019–20 season: Ballon d'Or nomination and Premier League title.
Alexander-Arnold began the <a href="2019-20%20Liverpool%20F.C.%20season">2019–20</a> campaign with his position as Liverpool's right-back cemented, and provided the assist for Origi's goal in the club's 4–1 opening game win over <a href="Norwich%20City%20F.C.">Norwich City</a>. In doing so, he became only the eighth player in the Premier League era to register an assist in five consecutive games, and the first to do so for Liverpool. He appeared in subsequent wins over <a href="Southampton%20F.C.">Southampton</a> and <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a>, as well as in Liverpool's triumph over <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> in the <a href="2019%20UEFA%20Super%20Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a> where he scored a penalty in the shoot-out. He then scored his first goal of the season during Liverpool's 2–1 league win over the Blues from a set-piece routine that was later nominated for the <a href="Premier%20League%20Goal%20of%20the%20Month">Premier League Goal of the Month</a> award. The following month, he was nominated for the <a href="2019%20Ballon%20d%27Or">2019 Ballon d'Or</a> award, alongside six of his Liverpool teammates.
On 2 November, at the age of 21 years and 26 days, he became the fourth-youngest player to reach 100 appearances for Liverpool, behind Owen, Sterling and Fowler, and marked the occasion by assisting Mané for the winning goal in a 2–1 victory over <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a>. Exactly one month later, he was voted as the 19th-best player in the world at the Ballon d'Or ceremony, and the highest-ranked full-back. He then made his <a href="FIFA%20Club%20World%20Cup">FIFA Club World Cup</a> debut during Liverpool's 2–1 semi-final win over reigning <a href="CONCACAF%20Champions%20League">CONCACAF</a> champions <a href="C.F.%20Monterrey">Monterrey</a>, and provided the match-winning assist for <a href="Roberto%20Firmino">Roberto Firmino</a> in stoppage time after coming on as a substitute for <a href="James%20Milner">James Milner</a>. Three days later, he started and played the full 120 minutes as Liverpool were crowned champions for the first time in the club's history following a 1–0 win after <a href="Extra%20time%20%28association%20football%29">extra time</a> over <a href="Copa%20Libertadores">Copa Libertadores</a> champions <a href="Clube%20de%20Regatas%20do%20Flamengo">Flamengo</a>.
Upon returning from Qatar, Liverpool recorded a 4–0 league win over second-placed <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a> during a match in which Alexander-Arnold played a hand in all four goals by scoring one, assisting two, and winning a penalty which was converted by Milner. He was later rewarded for his form with the <a href="Premier%20League%20Player%20of%20the%20Month">Premier League Player of the Month</a> award, becoming the first full-back to claim the honour since <a href="Micah%20Richards">Micah Richards</a> in 2007. Further recognition followed at the turn of the year, when he was named in the <a href="UEFA%20Team%20of%20the%20Year%23Team%20of%20the%20Year%202019">2019 UEFA Team of the Year</a>. Alexander-Arnold then played a starring role in Liverpool's 2–1 win over Wolves as the club extended their unbeaten run in the league to 40 matches. During the encounter, he assisted captain <a href="Jordan%20Henderson">Jordan Henderson</a> for the opening goal and in the process became the first defender in the competition's history to reach double figures for assists in multiple campaigns.
Towards the end of February, following a 3–2 win over <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United</a>, he matched his league assist record from the campaign before and took his overall tally in the Premier League to 25, becoming the third-youngest player in the competition's history to reach a quarter-century of assists behind <a href="Cesc%20F%C3%A0bregas">Cesc Fàbregas</a> and <a href="Wayne%20Rooney">Wayne Rooney</a>. The season was temporarily suspended between March and June due to the outbreak of the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, following which Alexander-Arnold helped Liverpool win their first league title in 30 years, and their first in the Premier League era. With the title secured, he then broke his own assist record on the penultimate day of the campaign when he set Firmino up to score in a 5–3 win over Chelsea. For his contributions during the season, he was awarded the inaugural <a href="Premier%20League%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Season">Premier League Young Player of the Season</a> award, won the PFA Young Player of the Year accolade and was named in the PFA Team of the Year.
2020–21 season: Further career milestones.
Alexander-Arnold continued to feature prominently for Liverpool during the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20Liverpool%20F.C.%20season">2020–21</a> campaign and, on 9 December, became the youngest-ever player to captain the club in European competition, and third-youngest in any competition, when he donned the armband during the Reds' 1–1 Champions League draw against <a href="FC%20Midtjylland">FC Midtjylland</a>. Later that month, he was named in the 2020 <a href="FIFPro%23FIFA_FIFPRO_Men%27s_World_11">FIFA FIFPro Men's World XI</a> alongside teammates <a href="Alisson">Alisson</a>, Van Dijk and <a href="Thiago%20Alc%C3%A2ntara">Thiago Alcântara</a>, althewhile Liverpool set about its domestic title defence by topping the league standings by Christmas. 
However, both his and the club's form waned in the second half of the campaign which culminated in Alexander-Arnold's highly-publicised omission from <a href="Gareth%20Southgate">Gareth Southgate</a>'s England squad for March's <a href="2022%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">2022 FIFA World Cup qualification</a> matches against <a href="San%20Marino%20national%20football%20team">San Marino</a>, <a href="Albania%20national%20football%20team">Albania</a> and <a href="Poland%20national%20football%20team">Poland</a>. As a result, his performances came under intense scrutiny following the international break and he was criticised for making defensive errors during Liverpool's 3–1 defeat to Real Madrid in the Champions League. In the Premier League, his form improved and he was lauded for his game-winning performances against Arsenal and <a href="Aston%20Villa">Aston Villa</a>, scoring the winning goal in the 90th minute of the latter fixture, and was shortlisted for the Premier League Player of the Month award for April. The following month, he recorded back-to-back assists in victories away to Manchester United, where Liverpool won for the first time in seven years, and <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a>, where his 94th-minute corner was headed home by goalkeeper Alisson to keep the club's hopes of qualifying for the following season's Champions League alive.
2021–22 season.
On 30 July, Alexander-Arnold signed a new long-term contract with Liverpool. On 16 December, Alexander-Arnold scored Liverpool's third goal in a 3–1 home win against <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a> with a 25 yard strike into the top left corner of the goal in what was Liverpool's <a href="Football%20records%20and%20statistics%20in%20England%23Wins">2000th top-flight win</a>, the first club in English history to reach this landmark.
International career.
Youth.
Alexander-Arnold has represented England at various youth levels and featured at the <a href="2015%20FIFA%20U-17%20World%20Cup">2015 FIFA U-17 World Cup</a> in Chile. He also scored three goals for the <a href="England%20national%20under-19%20football%20team">England U19</a> team, including a brace against <a href="Croatia%20national%20under-19%20football%20team">Croatia</a> and another against <a href="Spain%20national%20under-19%20football%20team">Spain</a> which secured England's qualification for the <a href="2017%20UEFA%20European%20Under-19%20Championship">2017 UEFA European Under-19 Championship</a>. He did not feature at the tournament itself as Liverpool reached an agreement with England to rest him ahead of the following season's league campaign, but the Three Lions went on to defeat <a href="Portugal%20national%20under-19%20football%20team">Portugal</a> in the final to claim their first ever title in the competition. The month following the tournament, he was called up to the <a href="England%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">England U21</a> team for the first time for their <a href="2019%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship%20qualification">UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualifiers</a> against <a href="Netherlands%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Netherlands</a> and <a href="Latvia%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Latvia</a>, and made his debut in a 3–0 win over the latter. Two more appearances followed with the U21 side before he was promoted and solidified his status within the senior <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> camp.
Senior.
In March 2018, while part of the U21 team, Alexander-Arnold was invited to train with the <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">senior national team</a> for the first time ahead of their friendly matches against <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a> and the <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands</a>. He received his first call-up in May 2018 when he was named in <a href="Gareth%20Southgate">Gareth Southgate</a>'s squad for the <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>. His debut followed on 7 June 2018 when he started in a 2–0 pre-tournament friendly win over <a href="Costa%20Rica%20national%20football%20team">Costa Rica</a> at <a href="Elland%20Road">Elland Road</a>. Prior to the match, he was handed his match jersey by <a href="Prince%20William%2C%20Duke%20of%20Cambridge">Prince William, Duke of Cambridge</a>. Alexander-Arnold then made his debut in the competition on 28 June, starting in a 1–0 group-stage defeat to <a href="Belgium%20national%20football%20team">Belgium</a>, after both sides had already confirmed their progression to the knockout stages. In doing so, he became only the fourth teenager to start a match for England at a World Cup. It remained, however, his only appearance as <a href="Kieran%20Trippier">Kieran Trippier</a> was preferred at right-back and featured throughout as England were defeated by <a href="Croatia%20national%20football%20team">Croatia</a> in the semi-finals, and then again by Belgium in the <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20knockout%20stage%23Third%20place%20play-off">third place play-off</a>.
On 15 November 2018, during a friendly international, held in honour of Wayne Rooney, Alexander-Arnold scored his first senior international goal as England recorded a 3–0 win over the <a href="United%20States%20men%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">United States</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a>. In doing so, and at the age of 20 years and 39 days, he became the youngest Liverpool player since Michael Owen in 1999 to score for the national team. In June 2019, he was part of the England squad which ended third at the inaugural <a href="UEFA%20Nations%20League">UEFA Nations League</a> and played the full match in a <a href="Penalty%20shoot-out%20%28association%20football%29">penalty shoot-out</a> win over <a href="Switzerland%20national%20football%20team">Switzerland</a> in the third-place play-off. Two years later, he was named in England's 26-man squad for the <a href="2020%20UEFA%20European%20Championship">2020 UEFA European Championship</a> but was forced to withdraw eight days before the competition commenced after sustaining a thigh injury during a pre-tournament friendly against <a href="Austria%20national%20football%20team">Austria</a>.
Style of play.
Alexander-Arnold is widely regarded as one of the best attacking full-backs in world football as a result of his proficiency at occupying attacking spaces on the pitch and creating goalscoring opportunities for his teammates. During the early years of his career, he emerged as one of the Premier League's most creative players due to his role in assisting goals from early <a href="Cross%20%28association%20football%29">crosses</a> and set-piece deliveries. He possesses an impressive passing range, which is attributed to his development as a <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> during his time in Liverpool's youth academy, and has been one of Liverpool's designated set-piece specialists for deadball situations since the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Liverpool%20F.C.%20season">2017–18 campaign</a>. His set-piece routine, which involves three parallel steps backwards and one to the right, has been likened to that of former <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> <a href="fly-half">fly-half</a> <a href="Jonny%20Wilkinson">Jonny Wilkinson</a>. Alexander-Arnold's craft and intelligence from deadball situations was singled out for particular praise by <a href="Gary%20Lineker">Gary Lineker</a> and <a href="Cesc%20F%C3%A0bregas">Cesc Fàbregas</a> after he assisted the winning goal in the 2018–19 Champions League semi-final by delivering a quickly-taken corner while the opposition players had their backs turned.
<a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> winner <a href="Cafu">Cafu</a> has heaped praise on the defender, saying "He’s a sensational player, a rare talent. He’s technically brilliant, he has so much quality. He has a Brazilian style of play. I love watching him play. And playing in such a great team will help him grow." <a href="Lionel%20Messi">Lionel Messi</a> has called him "Impressive" and remarked "[He is] the future, a fullback who is impressive going forward." Former <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> defender <a href="Gary%20Neville">Gary Neville</a> stated, "He's the best passer of a ball at right-back that I've ever seen. He's <a href="David%20Beckham">David Beckham</a> and <a href="Kevin%20De%20Bruyne">Kevin De Bruyne</a> at right-back". Under Liverpool manager <a href="J%C3%BCrgen%20Klopp">Jürgen Klopp</a>, whose tactical set-up placed creative responsibility on the shoulders of the club's full-backs, Alexander-Arnold was predominantly deployed down the right flank where his overlapping runs, switching of play, accuracy of crossing and work-rate in tracking back saw him become an important figure in the side's transitional, counter-attacking style of play.
Personal life.
Alexander-Arnold is the nephew of former <a href="Reading%20F.C.">Reading</a> and <a href="Millwall%20F.C.">Millwall</a> footballer, and former Manchester United club secretary, <a href="John%20Alexander%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201955%29">John Alexander</a>. His maternal grandmother, Doreen Carling, was once also in a relationship with former United manager, <a href="Sir%20Alex%20Ferguson">Sir Alex Ferguson</a>, before moving to New York City where she later married. Alexander-Arnold was thus eligible to play for the <a href="United%20States%20men%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">United States</a> prior to making his England debut. He has two brothers; Tyler, who is four years his senior and acts as his <a href="Sports%20agent">agent</a>, and Marcel, who is three years younger.
Outside of football, Alexander-Arnold volunteers as an ambassador for the Liverpool-based charity "An Hour for Others", which seeks to provide underprivileged members of the community with anything from food hampers and toys to cooking and science lessons. He has supported the charity since being introduced to it by his mother in his mid-teens. During his time with Liverpool's academy, he and teammate Kris Owens pledged to support the initiative if either of them made it as professional footballers. His philanthropy also expands beyond the charity and in March 2019, after signing a new boot sponsorship with <a href="Under%20Armour">Under Armour</a> (the second most lucrative boot deal in England behind <a href="Harry%20Kane">Harry Kane</a>'s) he initiated plans to purchase plots in Liverpool and use the funds to construct new pitches for the community.
He is also an avid <a href="chess">chess</a> player, having been introduced to the game by his father as a youngster, and in 2018 he played an invitational match against world champion <a href="Magnus%20Carlsen">Magnus Carlsen</a>. The match, which was played as part of a campaign to promote the sport, ended in defeat for Alexander-Arnold after seventeen moves; eight more than technology entrepreneur <a href="Bill%20Gates">Bill Gates</a> managed when he faced Carlsen in 2014. Alexander-Arnold later explained how chess was more than just a pastime and had helped him in his football career by teaching him to think "two or three moves ahead of the opposition".
In 2020, he and fellow Liverpool full-back <a href="Andrew%20Robertson">Andrew Robertson</a> starred in their own digital series on <a href="IGTV">IGTV</a> called "Wingmen".
